Indications and doses

Treatment of testicular, lung, cervical, bladder, head and neck, and ovarian cancer (alone or in combination),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Advice when patient is pregnant

Avoid (teratogenic and toxic in animal studies.

Most cytotoxic drugs are teratogenic and should not be administered during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester.

Considerable caution is necessary if a pregnant woman presents with cancer requiring chemotherapy, and specialist advice should always be sought.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Avoid if possible—nephrotoxic.

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Alopecia, bone-marrow suppression, extravasation, hyperuricaemia, hypomagnesaemia, myelosuppression, nephrotoxicity, oral mucositis, ototoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, severe nausea, severe vomiting, thromboembolism, tumour lysis syndrome,

Directions for administration

Cisplatin is increasingly given in a day care setting.

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA55

Paclitaxel for ovarian cancer (January 2003)

Either paclitaxel in combination with a platinum compound (cisplatin or carboplatin) or a platinum compound alone are alternatives for the first-line treatment of ovarian cancer (usually following surgery).

www.nice.org.uk/TA55 www.nice.org.uk/TA55

NICE TA91

Paclitaxel, pegylated liposomal doxorubicin, and topotecan for second-line or subsequent treatment of advanced ovarian cancer (May 2005)

Paclitaxel, combined with a platinum compound (carboplatin or cisplatin), is an option for advanced cancer that relapses 6 months or more after completing initial platinum-based chemotherapy.

www.nice.org.uk/TA91 www.nice.org.uk/TA91

Cautions regarding administration

  • Cisplatin requires intensive intravenous hydration and treatment may be complicated by severe nausea and vomiting.

Advice regarding conception and contraception

Exclude pregnancy before treatment with cytotoxic drugs.

Contraceptive advice should be given to men and women before cytotoxic therapy begins— manufacturer advises effective contraception during and for at least 6 months after treatment in men or women.

Regimens that do not contain an alkylating drug or procarbazine may have less effect on fertility, but those with an alkylating drug or procarbazine carry the risk of causing permanent male sterility (there is no effect on potency). Pretreatment counselling and consideration of sperm storage may be appropriate. Women are less severely affected, though the span of reproductive life may be shortened by the onset of a premature menopause. No increase in fetal abnormalities or abortion rate has been recorded in patients who remain fertile after cytotoxic chemotherapy.

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Nephrotoxicity

Monitoring of renal function is essential.

Monitor full blood count.

Monitor audiology.

Monitor plasma electrolytes.

Prepared medicinal forms of CISPLATIN
